Save the enclosure's current configuration to a file on a USB key plugged into the OA. The filename provided below must not contain any spaces, and it must have a .cfg extension. The file will be saved to the first USB key that was inserted into the OA.

The table below displays firmware versions for the components in this blade. Extended firmware information, manual discovery, and manual update may not be available until Enclosure Firmware Management is enabled. For more information see the Enclosure Firmware Management configuration page under Enclosure Settings.

The Onboard Administrator can be configured to manage the firmware components of the devices inside of the enclosure. A firmware ISO is required to discover extended firmware information or update firmware components. The Onboard Administrator can use a firmware ISO file that is hosted on an HTTP URL, a firmware ISO file on a USB key, or a DVD drive with firmware disc connected to the active OA.
By default, all bays are included in the automatic update and discovery process. Click the button below to configure which bays will be included in the process.
Manual Discovery and Manual Update only
Automatic Discovery of Firmware on Insertion
Automatic Update of Firmware on Insertion

The Enclosure IP Mode is a static IP address that always points to the Active Onboard Administrator in the enclosure. In the event that the Onboard Administrator changes roles this IP address can always be used to access the enclosure. This setting affects both IPv4 and IPv6.

The Onboard Administrator GUI login page displays certain pieces of anonymous data from the enclosure. This data is displayed in the linked enclosure table on the login page, and is also available through the Onboard Administrator's web service interface. You may disable the accessibility of this data below.

FIPS Mode ON is a FIPS 140-2 compliant mode that ensures that the OA is following cryptographic-based security requirements. This includes cryptographic algorithms, cryptographic key management techniques, and authentication techniques.

Save the current Configuration Script to a file on a USB Key which is plugged into the OA. The filename must use the USB file URL format (usb://d1/filename.cfg). The filename must not contain any spaces, and it must have a .cfg extension.

Use the button below to transition the redundancy state of the Onboard Administrators in this enclosure. This will cause the Onboard Administrators to switch each others' roles (also known as a takeover).

Strong passwords are required when changing FIPS modes.

Administrator password must contain at least one character from three of the four types of characters. The four types are Upper-case, Lower-case, Numeric and Non-alphanumeric. The password length must be between 8 and 40 characters.
The contents of the Enclosure Firmware Management Log will be cleared. Click OK to continue or Cancel to cancel.
The contents of all Enclosure Firmware Management Logs will be cleared. Click OK to continue or Cancel to cancel.

Enabling strong passwords will require that a user's password contain at least one character from three of the four types of characters. The four required character types are Upper-case, Lower-case, Numeric, and Non-alphanumeric.

Setting a minimum password length will require that a user's password contain at least the number of characters below. This value cannot be set below the system default of 3 characters, or above the maximum of 40 characters. Please note that changing this setting will only affect future password changes on existing accounts and new user accounts.

Setting a minimum password length will require that a user's password contain at least the number of characters below. This value cannot be set below the system default of 8 characters (when in FIPS MODE ON/DEBUG), or above the maximum of 40 characters. Please note that changing this setting will only affect future password changes on existing accounts and new user accounts.

Link Loss Failover will enable the Standby Onboard Administrator to monitor the network link status of the Active module. If the Active module loses its network link for a period of time and the Standby has reported a good link during the same time span, an automatic OA failover will occur. The interval before an automatic failover is performed can be defined below.

The session timeout below determines the number of minutes before inactive sessions are considered invalid. The session timeout value must be between 10 and 1440 (24 hours) inclusive. The session timeout can be disabled by setting it to zero.
If the session timeout value is lowered, currently inactive sessions may be removed.
Session options are not supported because this Onboard Administrator is running an older version of firmware. Please upgrade your Onboard Administrator to the latest version.

Do not directly apply a configuration script from another enclosure without removing or changing possibly unique settings such as the enclosure Asset Tag, enclosure name, static IP addresses and EBIPA settings.

Resetting the factory defaults will restore all of your enclosure's settings to their initial factory values. The Onboard Administrator will be reset in order for the changes to take effect.

All user accounts except for the built-in Administrator account will be removed (the built-in Administrator account password will not be reset). All AlertMail, Network and Network Protocol, SNMP, and Power Management settings will be reset. All Onboard Administrators (Active and Standby) will use DHCP for their network settings. The syslogs for both the Active and Standby Onboard Administrators will be cleared.
to download a script containing your current configuration. This script can be used later to restore settings that were lost after a factory reset.

In this configuration N power supplies are used to provide power and N are used to provide redundancy, where N can equal 1, 2 or 3. When correctly wired with redundant DC line feeds this will ensure that a DC line feed failure will not cause the enclosure to power off.

In this configuration N power supplies are used to provide power and N are used to provide redundancy, where N can equal 1, 2 or 3. When correctly wired with redundant AC line feeds this will ensure that an AC line feed failure will not cause the enclosure to power off.

Up to 6 power supplies can be installed with one power supply always reserved to provide redundancy. In the event of a single power supply failure the redundant power supply will take over the load. A power line feed failure or failure of more than one power supply will cause the system to power off.

No power redundancy rules are enforced and power redundancy warnings will not be given. If all of the power supplies are needed to supply Present Power, the failure of a power supply or power feed to the enclosure may cause the enclosure to brown-out.

The Onboard Administrator allocates power in the enclosure based on device power requests. These devices include server blades, interconnect modules, fans, and Onboard Administrator modules. Enclosure allocated power is an aggregate of the allocated power for all the devices.
The watts available are based on the enclosure's current redundancy mode. Watts available is equal to the enclosure's total power minus the amount required to sustain redundancy.

Note: Power allocation is not a present reading of the enclosure's power draw. It is a potential maximum number which is calculated for the enclosure. For example, a server with multiple CPUs and full memory running at full CPU utilization will approach its allocated wattage, but at any given time may be using less than its allocation.

You have configured this enclosure with N+N redundant power. In order to achieve the benefits of N+N redundancy, the power supplies on the A side of the enclosure must be on a different branch circuit from those on the B side. Each branch circuit must be sized to carry the full load of the enclosure in the event of power loss to a side.

Average power will not exceed Dynamic Power Cap or Derated Circuit Capacity. Peak power will not exceed Rated Circuit Capacity. For example, suppose the PDU powering the enclosure has a rated capacity of 30 amps. In North America and Japan, the standard de-rating ratio is 80%, so the PDU has a derated capacity of 24 amps (0.80 * 30). At 208 volts, the Rated Circuit Capacity would be entered as 6240 watts (30 * 208), and the Derated Circuit Capacity would be entered as 4992 watts (24 * 208). The Derated Circuit Capacity must be at least as large as the Dynamic Power Cap and no larger than the Rated Circuit Capacity. The Dynamic Power Cap can be used to limit the enclosure's power consumption based on a cooling constraint that may be lower than the Derated Circuit Capacity.
The Present Power reading is the actual measurement of DC input power drawn by the enclosure and all devices.
The Present Power reading is a calculated measurement of DC input power drawn by the enclosure and all devices.
The Present Power reading is a calculated measurement of AC input power drawn by the enclosure and all devices.
The Present Power reading is the actual measurement of AC input power drawn by the enclosure and all devices.
The AC input Wattage draw is calculated for the enclosure (including all of its devices) based on the known AC Wattage values obtained from the enclosure's power supplies.
The AC input Wattage draw is an approximation calculated for the enclosure (including all of its devices) based on the known DC Wattage values obtained from the enclosure's power supplies.
The DC input Wattage draw is an approximation calculated for the enclosure (including all of its devices) based on the known DC Wattage values obtained from the enclosure's power supplies.
The Power Limit value can change depending on the current Power Mode (power redundancy setting) and the number and location of power supplies.
Device Bay iLO Processor Address Range:

The form below provides fixed IP address assignment to the device bays in the enclosure. If there is an IP address in the Current Address column, the device (iLO) has previously been configured or has received a DHCP address.

All of the selected iLO Processors will be reset if the protocol is enabled. If each iLO has been previously given a static IP address, these EBIPA settings will not change the static IP address. If the iLO IP address has been configured via an external DHCP service, the EBIPA settings will override the existing DHCP address.
When EBIPA is configured the network is checked for duplicate IP addresses. This process may take several minutes, especially if multiple enclosures have been selected.
Interconnect Bay Management Port Address Range:

The form below provides fixed IP address assignment to the interconnect bays in the rear of the enclosure. If there is an IP address in the Current Address column, the interconnect device has previously been configured or has received a DHCP address.

If each interconnect has been previously given a static IP address, these EBIPA settings will not change the static IP address. If the interconnect management IP address has been configured via an external DHCP service, the EBIPA settings will override the existing DHCP address.

The graphic below displays the enclosure link and OA/iLO connections on the rear of the enclosure. An explanation of each port is given below the graphic.
Ports and their use (from left to right):
Enclosure link downlink port - Use this port to connect the enclosure link to the enclosure below this enclosure.
Enclosure link uplink port and service port - Use this port to connect the enclosure link to the enclosure above this enclosure. This port is also used to connect a service PC.
OA/iLO Port 1 - Ethernet link for the Onboard Administrator in bay 1 and all iLO management processors.
OA/iLO Port 2 - Ethernet link for the Onboard Administrator in bay 2 and all iLO management processors.
UID Light - The enclosure's unit identification LED. Note: this graphic does not reflect the current state of the UID.
Link Loss Failover settings can be configured even if the enclosure has no management redundancy. The settings will not take effect unless a redundant Onboard Administrator is present.
This mezzanine device does not have rear I/O connectivity.

Use the bay selection below to select the bays which will be included in the firmware management process. This setting applies to the automatic update, automatic discovery policy and scheduled update operations only.

To perform a manual firmware update, select the server bays below and click Start Manual Update. Once the firmware update process has begun, the selected servers will be reset and placed into Enclosure Firmware Management mode. The update process will take several minutes for each server that has been selected.

To perform a manual firmware discovery, select the server bays below and click Start Manual Discovery. Once the firmware discovery process has begun, the selected servers will be reset and placed into Enclosure Firmware Management mode. The discovery process will take several minutes for each server that has been selected.

To schedule a one-time firmware update, enter a valid date and time below. Both date and time must be specified. To select the devices that will be updated, choose them from the Bays to Include section below.
Enclosure Firmware Management discovery and update operations can be initiated manually. To discover or update devices manually, click one of the buttons below.
The Enclosure Firmware Management update policy determines when the firmware management process will run.

Enclosure Firmware Management is not supported on the standby OA hardware present. The feature will be disabled if the standby OA becomes Active.
Critical indicates that immediate action is needed, because it can result in imminent suspension of operation or critical resources.
Major indicates that quick action is needed, because it can result in imminent suspension of operation or critical resources.
Minor indicates that action is needed. However, it need not be acted upon immediately.
Informational indicates that the event contains information for reference.
Normal indicates that the severity level is normal.
Unknown indicates that the severity level is unknown.
Enclosure Firmware Management indicates that a device is in firmware management mode.

HP Insight Remote Support offers 24x7 remote monitoring for HP devices and provides automatic notifications, accurate diagnosis, and faster problem resolution for hardware issues.

Register your enclosure to communicate directly to HP without the need to set up an HP Insight Remote Support centralized hosting device in your local environment. HP Insight Online will be your primary interface for remote support information. Insight Online is a secure web portal where you can monitor your remote support devices, track service events, support cases, contracts and warranties and view configuration and inventory details. Learn more at www.hp.com/go/insightonline/info

Register your enclosure to communicate to HP through an HP Insight Remote Support centralized hosting device in your local environment. All configuration and service event information is routed through this hosting device. This information can be viewed using the local HP Insight Remote Support user interface, plus the optional web-based view in HP Insight Online.
Quick Setup for HP Insight Remote Support

The range entered is not adequate for the number of interconnect bays.
Interconnect Bay Management Port Address Range:

The form below provides fixed IPv6 address assignment to the interconnect bays in the rear of the enclosure. If there is an IPv6 address in the EBIPA Address field, the interconnect device has previously been configured or has received a DHCPv6 address.

If each interconnect has been previously given a static IPv6 address, these EBIPAV6 settings will not change the static IPv6 address. If the interconnect management IPv6 address has been configured via an external DHCPv6 service, the EBIPAV6 settings will override the existing DHCPv6 address only after lease expiration.
This list displays the IPv6 addresses that will be assigned to each of the interconnect bays if EBIPAV6 is enabled.

Clicking the autofill "down arrow" button will fill in consecutive IPv6 addresses for all of the interconnect bays below the arrow. The domain and DNS servers will also be copied to each of the consecutive bays in the list.
This list displays the IPv6 addresses that will be assigned to each of the device bays if EBIPAV6 is enabled.

Clicking the autofill "down arrow" button will fill in consecutive IPv6 addresses for all of the device bays below the arrow. The domain and DNS servers will also be copied to each of the consecutive bays in the list.
Device Bay iLO Processor Address Range:

The form below provides fixed IPv6 address assignment to the device bays in the enclosure. If there is an IPv6 address in the EBIPA Address field, the device (iLO) has previously been configured or has received a DHCPv6 address.

All of the selected iLO Processors will be reset if the protocol is enabled. If each iLO has been previously given a static IPv6 address, these EBIPAv6 settings will not change the static IPv6 address. If the iLO IPv6 address has been configured via an external DHCPv6 service, the EBIPAv6 settings will override the existing DHCPv6 address.
When EBIPAv6 is configured the network is checked for duplicate IPv6 addresses. This process may take several minutes, especially if multiple enclosures have been selected.
